title: 107_hr5596
content: Exemption for certain state and local political committees from notification and reporting requirements under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendments allow political committees of state or local candidates, as well as state or local committees of political parties, to be exempt from certain notification and reporting requirements. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 exempt qualified State or local political organizations from certain notification and reporting requirements. These organizations are defined as political entities solely focused on influencing the selection of individuals for State or local public offices. State or local political organizations subject to State law requiring reporting. The curr_chunk states that organizations must provide information on expenditures, contributions, and the individuals involved. Organizations must report expenditures, contributions, and individuals involved, with certain state law differences disregarded. The organization must report the occupation of contributors, recipients of expenditures, purpose of expenditures, and dates of contributions and expenditures. The organization must report details such as the occupation of contributors, recipients of expenditures, purpose of expenditures, and dates of contributions and expenditures. An organization will not lose its status as a qualified State or local political organization for minor errors in complying with reporting and inspection requirements, as long as the errors are corrected promptly. Additionally, a qualified State or local political organization cannot include a federal candidate or office holder who controls or significantly participates in the organization, or solicits contributions unless deemed insignificant and done without prior knowledge or consent. The amendments made by this section regarding prior knowledge and consent of the organization or its officers, directors, agents, or employees, and directing disbursements by the organization, shall take effect as if included in Public Law 106-230. SEC. 3. EXEMPTION FROM ANNUAL RETURN REQUIREMENTS. Income Tax Returns Required Only for Political Organization. Taxable Income paragraph of section 6012(a) of the Internal Revenue Code amended. Income Tax Returns Not Subject to Disclosure. Amendments made to disclosure and public inspection sections of the Code. Information Returns section amended for political organizations. This section applies to political organizations with gross receipts of $25,000 or more, or $100,000 for qualified State or local political organizations. They must file an annual return with required information for tax-exempt organizations, and additional details as deemed necessary by the Secretary. Exceptions apply for certain organizations. Political organizations meeting specific criteria must file an annual return with the required information for tax-exempt organizations. The Secretary has the discretion to exempt certain organizations from this filing requirement. The Secretary can exempt organizations from filing an information return if deemed unnecessary for efficient tax administration. The amendments made by this section will be retroactively effective. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Federal Election Commission, will publicize the effect of the amendments made by the Act and the interaction of reporting requirements under section 527 of the Internal Revenue Code and the Federal Election Campaign Act. Information provided will be included in guidance issued to the public. Additionally, organizations may be exempt from filing amounts as deemed necessary for tax administration efficiency. SEC. 5. WAIVER OF FILING AMOUNTS. The Secretary may waive taxes or amounts imposed on organizations for non-compliance if failure was due to reasonable cause. Effective after June 30, 2000. SEC. 6. MODIFICATIONS TO SECTION 527 ORGANIZATION DISCLOSURE PROVISIONS. (a) Unsegregated Funds Not To Avoid Tax.--Paragraph (4) of section 527(i) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include exempt function income whether or not segregated. (b) Procedures for Assessment and Collection of Amounts.--Amounts imposed under section 527(j) shall be assessed and collected like penalties under section 6652(c). (c) Duplicate Written Filings Not Required.--Written filings under section 527(i)(1) can now be done electronically only. (d) Application of Fraud Penalty.--Fraud penalties under section 7207 apply to fraudulent returns and statements. The Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include electronic filing requirements for reports with contributions or expenditures exceeding $50,000. Notices of material changes must be given within 30 days, and failure to do so will result in adjustments to income and deductions. The amendments apply to failures occurring after the enactment of this Act. The Act specifies effective dates for various subsections, including amendments for reports and notices required to be filed after the enactment date. Amendments for material changes apply to reports filed more than 30 days after enactment, with a specific date for reports filed after June 30, 2003. Material changes occurring after enactment require notices under section 527(i) within a 30-day period. After the enactment of this Act, a notice under section 527(i) of the Internal Revenue Code shall not be required to be filed before 30 days after a material change or 45 days after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 7. EFFECT OF AMENDMENTS ON EXISTING DISCLOSURES. Notices, reports, or returns filed with the Secretary of the Treasury before the enactment of the amendments shall remain subject to disclosure provisions of section 6104 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
